positive.review:
Overall: fun. 

Disclaimer: I brought the game for the Va-11 Ha11a or however you spell it collab, liking the original game. Jill is a fine character, and Dorothy, although a paid character, is my main and really fun. I only play PVE, and do not have even half the characters. But I have enough characters to have fun with. 

I'm not 100% fluent in the terminology as well, and I can't be bothered to look up names.

With the right characters and for a gamble (gacha) game, it's not that bad especially compared to competitors. There's no limitations on playing games, just a bit of a bottle neck on rewards for playing PVE. I would say it's one of the cheaper gachas to get a relatively good range of characters, and I splurged on some skins. Most of which, you don't need to even gamble for. If this changes for the worst, and i'm still playing, I will try to remember to edit this.

Wouldn't really say it's that lewd, obviously there's no actual nudity unless you're from countries like Saudia Arabia. Characters are well designed visually, with a good variety.

Main complaints are: 
There's a definite character heirarchy leading to unfun games with certain characters. The main characters are able to carry games practically solo whilst you'll struggle to get a single kill with others. Could use some balancing, but it's not as bad as it might seem and you can have fun with all the cast.

Do not bother with AI PVE games. The AI will not attack any enemies that progress the game, so it's a genuine challenge to even beat most of the PVE fights with all AI other than you. I wish this would change, but alas.

Lobbying can be hit or miss. Especially when you're new and are trying for the Nightmare or Insane difficulties. Making your own room helps but isn't that good.

It is a dice game, go in with the knowledge that there will be sometimes when you get ganged by the AI, especially in higher difficulties.

Some of the English translation shows as being translated, for instance, 'You play it well' is the English phrase instead of 'Well Played'. It adds a bit of character, but some of the descriptions do get kind of confusion when reading them the first time, like 'the event' rather than 'land on event space'.

Not really a negative. Communication is fine for the most part, I just wish that there was a way to communicate what cards you have in PVE, or just see your allies' cards.

Positives:
Gacha, at least for what I wanted, was not too bad. I don't think I spent over Â£20, (minus the skins) which might seem alot for about half the cast, but for gachas and mostly without needing to gamble, that's cheaper than I would expect.

The random selectable abilities make PVE games dynamic, and some combinations are really fun (like Dorothy and the skill refresh -1 cost, lets you wiz around the stage every turn). At higher PVE levels you can get rerolls, which adds strategy as they're limited so you need to choose when to reroll, either when the better rewards are higher % or to get a good start.

Most characters have some good range of emotes, some are definitely better than others though and especially before bonding this is true.

The combat is straight forward, and fun with a lot of personality, with skins adding a lot of this to make it fresh.

Music is works and some songs hit hard, like the newest PVE map.

No limitation on number of games you can play, aside from getting into games themselves. (Again, wouldn't really recommend AI PVE games, pvp seems mediocre but I don't really play it, nor do many others.) Doesn't seem like it needs to be a positive, but it's a f2p game, and I want to respect that they didn't use some ticket, fuel, energy or other nonsense to limit the amount of games you can play.

In this game, there's a stupid randomness that I didn't like at all! At the very beginning of the player's level 1, I picked the character Fen, and with the help of this character, I only leveled up with him and chose only the coolest characters for myself, leveling them up exclusively. I considered the others to be simply boring, I only played the coolest characters. As a result, we won almost every PVE game, even when the time was short and the difficulty was insane! Whoever is interested, these characters are just fire for me! 1-Jill 2-Mesh Hero 3-Robot maid 4-Cheongsam girl.
lowk should add more men but its a fun game when ur playing pvp with friends. i just wish they added an option to have more than 4 people play in pvp

Astral Party is way more fun than I expected. Itâ€™s got that chaotic â€œMario Party but animeâ€ vibe, with dice rolls, cards, and random events that can totally flip the match. The characters are cute, the maps look great, and itâ€™s easy to jump in with friends.

Positive: update once in two months, new potential skills characters, triggers, chips...

Everytime you play pvp, there will always that teamer targeting you, keep killing you, dragging you through the pavement, and there's nothing you can do. Feels good when you win though.

It's a fun game, it reminds me of Dokapon kingdom but has more chaos. It more than a few games to really get in the flow and understanding what's going on. The game has several different maps with different types of enemies and goals. You have some many rounds to finish the objectives and there is special rounds that have effects (Has a monsters face instead of a number, which you can click to read what event will occur) The bosses are unique to the stages as well. Enjoyable game overall.

I would like to offer the following observations and suggestions, hoping they can serve as a reference for future optimizations:

I. Regarding the use of art assets (a truly regrettable aspect)

I noticed that many high-quality art assets in the game are not being fully utilized, which I find regrettable.

The display time for hit-and-run illustrations is too short: Each character has a beautifully drawn illustration when attacked, but these are displayed on the field for less than a second, making them difficult for players to see clearly.

Monster illustrations have low utilization: You have drawn exquisite illustrations for each Boss and monster, but these illustrations can only be fully viewed when clicking on the "Encyclopedia." In actual combat, monster attacks are displayed as small icons. Suggestion: It is hoped that these existing art assets can be better displayed in combat, allowing players to directly experience the art team's hard work, rather than just being hidden in the encyclopedia.

II. The combat pacing issue that seriously affects the experience

This is currently the most detrimental aspect to my playability: the turns occupied by monsters are far too long.

In the late game, there are often more than 10 monsters, and players must wait for them to roll the dice, move, and attack one by one, taking about one second each.

In multiplayer mode, all players must watch other players "watch monster animations," resulting in two-thirds of the game time being spent waiting (commonly known as "garbage time"). Actual gameplay time is very limited, making it extremely tiring. An average game lasting over an hour and a half is simply outrageous.

III. Specific Improvement Proposal: Synchronizing Enemy Turns
To address the aforementioned pacing issue, I propose separating the turn mechanics of "minions" and "bosses."

Minion Turn Synchronization: All minions complete their actions simultaneously within the same turn.

Four-Panel Screen Display: During a minion's turn, the screen can be divided into four panels (or other division methods corresponding to the number of players), displaying the animation of each player being attacked by a minion. This preserves the visual presentation of the animations while significantly reducing waiting time, allowing everyone to complete a minion turn as quickly as possible. The boss can maintain independent actions to highlight its importance.

IV. Other Interface and Localization Issues

The most significant factor affecting my willingness to play is the excessively long turn time taken up by monsters.

The card description font is too small: While you might get used to it after playing for a while, it's not user-friendly for new players or those who struggle with reading.

The Traditional Chinese localization is incomplete: The current Traditional Chinese version still contains many Simplified Chinese characters. These details may seem minor, but they accumulate over time and affect the game's overall refinement and reputation.

Thank you again for developing this game; I sincerely hope it continues to improve.

Its like Mario Party, but its anime with combat mechanic.

This is a fun, casual party game featuring anime characters â€” kind of like Mario Party, but with cards, unique character abilities, and a bit of strategy. It can feel a little overwhelming at first since every character has its own mechanics, but after a few rounds (or a quick look at the wiki), it starts to make sense.

Thereâ€™s a tutorial mode with bots, which I recommend if you're just starting out. Once you get the hang of the abilities and cards, the game becomes pretty relaxed. Itâ€™s not too stressful, but you do need to think a few moves ahead.

The character roster is diverse, and you're likely to find someone who fits your playstyle. Some characters definitely feel stronger or easier to use than others, and not everyone will enjoy every character â€” but thatâ€™s part of the fun. I like rotating through all of them to keep things interesting.

There are two main modes: PvP and PvE (co-op). PvP is... fine. Itâ€™s definitely more enjoyable with friends. Playing with randoms can be frustrating, and if your username isnâ€™t in Chinese, you might notice you get targeted more often â€” which can really take the fun out of it. Iâ€™d only recommend PvP if youâ€™re going in with a group.

PvE is where the game shines. Co-op sessions can be really fun and engaging â€” when they go well. The downside is that some teammates go AFK or rage-quit when things arenâ€™t going their way. As someone who mostly plays solo, thatâ€™s a big downside. It wastes time, especially when youâ€™re just trying to complete daily missions.

Speaking of dailies, the tasks are pretty low-effort. One session per day is usually enough. Depending on your team and how things play out, matches can take anywhere from 20 minutes to an hour.
Performance-wise, the game is lightweight and runs smoothly. You can resize the window freely, which is great if you like to multitask or just want to play casually in the background.

Now, yes â€” there is a gacha mechanic. You wonâ€™t have access to every character from the start. But in my experience, the gacha rates are pretty generous. I was able to unlock most of the characters quickly (within a week of playing daily) just by completing missions and dailies. Of course, thatâ€™s just my experience, so take it with a grain of salt.

One more thing to note: the game also has limited-time offers for skins and certain collaborative characters. Once these offers expire, those items are gone for good. Keep that in mind if youâ€™re interested â€” itâ€™s a gacha game after all.

Oh, and people seem to be comparing this to 100% Orange Juice, which I canâ€™t say much about since I donâ€™t play 100% Orange Juice. ğŸ˜­

Overall, if youâ€™re into free anime aesthetics, card-based gameplay, and casual co-op, this is a fun, low-pressure game thatâ€™s easy to pick up and gradually rewarding as you get more familiar with the mechanics. Just be aware of the gacha.

I still play this game for now, but in the future, I'll probably drop it when I lose interest or it gets too much content and a heavy load.

TL;DR A Super fun amazing looking 10/10 f2p friendly roguelike-ish party game

As a fan of 100%OJ, I still find this game to be a LOT more fun. What makes it more fun you say? Here comes the big list (Disclaimer: I barely played the PvP mode which is mostly dead, this review solely focuses on PvE mode which is where playerbase is actually active): 
Number 1: No unlockable cards, all non-character-specific cards are already drawable without any need to unlock them through gacha similar to 100OJ. 
Number 2: Really fun gameplay with a cool level-up system with huge variety of enchantments which make really dope synergies both together AND with character specific skills. Getting the right build of encahntments can be a gamechanger, making the game feel a bit rogue-like-ish. 
Number 3: REALLY cool, cute and quirky aesthetics and art-style plus a SUPER good OST which remind me to that of DohnaDohna. 
Number 4: Really well designed characters with both a full body art and in-game chibi art (unlike OJ which only has the chibi) 
Number 5: SUPER F2P friendly; out of all the gacha games I currently play (Riichi City, Mahjong Soul and ZZZ) this one is by far more generous with its gacha. I already pulled 4 characters which one of them I had an eye for (Al) and I also unlocked Jill the crossover character after a few days of daily login. No other games would give you a CROSSOVER character THIS easily for simply playing the game (while OJ is also really generous with its rewards, keep in mind that OJ is still a paid game while this one is F2P) 
Number 6: THE EMOTES MAN! OMG The emotes are so goddamn funny! They are mostly refrences to famous anime frames or memes in general. And they work great. Everyone should embrace the memes. 
Number 7: Did I mention how cool the enchantment synergies are?

Now for the downsides: 
Number 1: Seemingly smaller playerbase which could be the result of some brain-dead wokies review bombing the game (Explains why the game is tagged as "hentai" while it clearly isn't lol) The PvE (co-op) mode is always active but almost no-one plays the PvP mode. Which isn't that much of an issue, since I feel like PvE is just more fun than PvP and even if you really wanted to play PvP, you could just do it with your friends (Personally I think PvE is just a lot more fun but it's a matter of taste) As you can say, this isn't that much of a con since it's a community issue rather than a problem with the game itself.
......aaand that's about it for all the real cons.

Mixed features: This section is for the features that could be interpretated as both a downside and an upside depending on how you look at it. 
Number 1: There is no free chat in this game like OJ. You can only send emojis and some default messages like "thank you" or "heal me please". While it removes the ability to properly communicate with team members during matches and set strategy, I feel like it makes the environment FAR more pure and less toxic than OJ so people can never show their ugly side and every seem pure as the anime girls they are playing as which is really heartwarming. And tbf, I don't think most players need advice on how to play the game as it's both easy to understand and bosses are also a piece of cake as long as there is one player who accumulated enough damage to take it down. So imo, the limit of chatting is more of an upside than a downside.
Number 2: Gameplay kind of slow. Why is it mixed? Because with slow gameplay, you can actually relax and read the description of every card and enchantment and calmly make good decisions, making the game super newbie friendly compared to OJ. And usually no one rushes you unless you take extra long time to finish your turn which even if you do, game starts to shorten your timer for the next turn. This one, is also more of an upside in my opinion.

Overall, a 10/10 hella fun game to play, either with randoms or friends. I mostly play with randoms and still have tons of fun. Admittedly I haven't even opened 100%OJ since I started playing this game. Not to say OJ is bad, it's just that this game does it much better. So yeah, highly recommend this one to anyone looking for something similar to 100% Orange Juice.

Genuinely a good replacement if not everyone in the friend group owns Mario Party/Nintendo Online. Though the fan service can be a bit too much for some people, it still ends up being an enjoyable and fun game all throughout in addition to it's very generous gacha pulls.

I would like to offer the following observations and suggestions, hoping they can serve as a reference for future optimizations:

I. Regarding the use of art assets (a truly regrettable aspect)

I noticed that many high-quality art assets in the game are not being fully utilized, which I find regrettable.

The display time for hit-and-run illustrations is too short: Each character has a beautifully drawn illustration when attacked, but these are displayed on the field for less than a second, making them difficult for players to see clearly.

Monster illustrations have low utilization: You have drawn exquisite illustrations for each Boss and monster, but these illustrations can only be fully viewed when clicking on the "Encyclopedia." In actual combat, monster attacks are displayed as small icons. Suggestion: It is hoped that these existing art assets can be better displayed in combat, allowing players to directly experience the art team's hard work, rather than just being hidden in the encyclopedia.

II. The combat pacing issue that seriously affects the experience

This is currently the most detrimental aspect to my playability: the turns occupied by monsters are far too long.

In the late game, there are often more than 10 monsters, and players must wait for them to roll the dice, move, and attack one by one, taking about one second each.

In multiplayer mode, all players must watch other players "watch monster animations," resulting in two-thirds of the game time being spent waiting (commonly known as "garbage time"). Actual gameplay time is very limited, making it extremely tiring. An average game lasting over an hour and a half is simply outrageous.

III. Specific Improvement Proposal: Synchronizing Enemy Turns
To address the aforementioned pacing issue, I propose separating the turn mechanics of "minions" and "bosses."

Minion Turn Synchronization: All minions complete their actions simultaneously within the same turn.

Four-Panel Screen Display: During a minion's turn, the screen can be divided into four panels (or other division methods corresponding to the number of players), displaying the animation of each player being attacked by a minion. This preserves the visual presentation of the animations while significantly reducing waiting time, allowing everyone to complete a minion turn as quickly as possible. The boss can maintain independent actions to highlight its importance.

IV. Other Interface and Localization Issues

The most significant factor affecting my willingness to play is the excessively long turn time taken up by monsters.

The card description font is too small: While you might get used to it after playing for a while, it's not user-friendly for new players or those who struggle with reading.

The Traditional Chinese localization is incomplete: The current Traditional Chinese version still contains many Simplified Chinese characters. These details may seem minor, but they accumulate over time and affect the game's overall refinement and reputation.

Thank you again for developing this game; I sincerely hope it continues to improve.

This is a fun, casual party game featuring anime characters â€” kind of like Mario Party, but with cards, unique character abilities, and a bit of strategy. It can feel a little overwhelming at first since every character has its own mechanics, but after a few rounds (or a quick look at the wiki), it starts to make sense.

Thereâ€™s a tutorial mode with bots, which I recommend if you're just starting out. Once you get the hang of the abilities and cards, the game becomes pretty relaxed. Itâ€™s not too stressful, but you do need to think a few moves ahead.

The character roster is diverse, and you're likely to find someone who fits your playstyle. Some characters definitely feel stronger or easier to use than others, and not everyone will enjoy every character â€” but thatâ€™s part of the fun. I like rotating through all of them to keep things interesting.

There are two main modes: PvP and PvE (co-op). PvP is... fine. Itâ€™s definitely more enjoyable with friends. Playing with randoms can be frustrating, and if your username isnâ€™t in Chinese, you might notice you get targeted more often â€” which can really take the fun out of it. Iâ€™d only recommend PvP if youâ€™re going in with a group.

PvE is where the game shines. Co-op sessions can be really fun and engaging â€” when they go well. The downside is that some teammates go AFK or rage-quit when things arenâ€™t going their way. As someone who mostly plays solo, thatâ€™s a big downside. It wastes time, especially when youâ€™re just trying to complete daily missions.

Speaking of dailies, the tasks are pretty low-effort. One session per day is usually enough. Depending on your team and how things play out, matches can take anywhere from 20 minutes to an hour.
Performance-wise, the game is lightweight and runs smoothly. You can resize the window freely, which is great if you like to multitask or just want to play casually in the background.

Now, yes â€” there is a gacha mechanic. You wonâ€™t have access to every character from the start. But in my experience, the gacha rates are pretty generous. I was able to unlock most of the characters quickly (within a week of playing daily) just by completing missions and dailies. Of course, thatâ€™s just my experience, so take it with a grain of salt.

One more thing to note: the game also has limited-time offers for skins and certain collaborative characters. Once these offers expire, those items are gone for good. Keep that in mind if youâ€™re interested â€” itâ€™s a gacha game after all.

Oh, and people seem to be comparing this to 100% Orange Juice, which I canâ€™t say much about since I donâ€™t play 100% Orange Juice. ğŸ˜­

Overall, if youâ€™re into free anime aesthetics, card-based gameplay, and casual co-op, this is a fun, low-pressure game thatâ€™s easy to pick up and gradually rewarding as you get more familiar with the mechanics. Just be aware of the gacha.

I still play this game for now, but in the future, I'll probably drop it when I lose interest or it gets too much content and a heavy load.

I was really excited for this game when it was announced, it seemed like a more modern version of 100% Orange Juice, the character designs are extremely appealing, and on top of that, there were hints that this would eventually release as a mobile game (I've always wanted a version of 100%OJ that could be played on the go).

When the demo dropped, I was very underwhelmed, the game was clearly far from finished, there were a lot of translation bugs, things that are essential for card games like a card history are simply missing, and the UI is far from polished (some menus literally use default Unity UI elements, ffs), but, worst of all, there was no setting to adjust the game speed, I'll talk more about this later because it's very important for this kind of game, but the main point is, it didn't seem like a game that was supposed to launch a month later, heck, I'd even dare to say it needed at least a year of polish before being in a presentable state for an official launch,

I thought to myself "there is no way this demo represents the current stage of development of the game, it surely must have been compiled a few months ago", and "maybe they will collect feedback from the demo and most problems should be fixed by release". Boy was I wrong.

Where do I start? Most of the game is exactly the same as the demo, the translation errors still remain, card history is still missing, the UI is still hot garbage, and the gameplay itself is still painfully slow, with no option to accelerate it. The only thing that changed between the demo and the official release was the inclusion of the gacha mechanic and other F2P elements.

Let me start by saying I have no problem with the gacha mechanic itself, after all this is a F2P game, it must make money somehow, although I can't avoid thinking it's kind of a cash grab since the game itself is crowdfunded on top of that, especially since the prices are outrageous: almost 15 USD for 10 rolls. You can only buy rolls with real currency btw, no option to use the in-game premium currency (which you can also buy with real money). Speaking of currencies, there are like SEVEN different in-game currencies, and the game makes almost 0 effort in trying to explain you what each one is for or how to get them, you'll have to figure that out by yourself.

Most of the issues I just described are no big deal, because both the premium currency and the gacha rolls can be grinded by playing and completing missions, so as long as the gameplay is fun, everything is fine, right?

This is where I come back to the point I made about the game speed. The game is horribly slow, a single match can go for upwards of an hour, and you're forced to sit through long and slow movement animations, not to mention the laughably short background music that loops every 30 seconds, making you go insane. Playing this game, even if you're not grinding for characters or items, quickly becomes a chore. You feel like you're being held hostage by the game, and just want it to end as soon as possible, I've even gone as far as helping someone else win because I just wanted it to be over. This is really not an enjoyable experience for anyone involved.

If just playing the game for fun already feels like a chore, imagine trying to grind for characters or items, It would be literally torture. This game need a speed slider ASAP, I think this is the biggest issue the devs need to address, and it shouldn't take them too long considering they are using Unity, just change the global animation speed multiplier and you'll instantly make this a more enjoyable experience.

The devs should really aim for 15 minute matches if they want this game to succeed, ESPECIALLY if they plan to make this a mobile game. This is the kind of game you'll want to play in between work shifts, during short breaks or during your commute, having matches go on for longer than 15 minutes is simply unacceptable in those contexts, let alone 1 hour.

I really can't recommend this game in its current state, even early access games are usually far more polished than this, this really feels like a prototype more than an official release. However, the core gameplay is really fun and I think this game as a lot of potential, so if/when the devs fix the issues described here (especially the speed, PLEASE), I'll change my review to match. Until then, I won't play or recommend this game.

TL;DR: VERY unpolished game, matches are too long and feel like a chore, confusing gacha mechanics. Has potential if it fixes those issues, but overall it was released TOO early.

I hopped on to play a bit with the VA11HALLA collab and I was kinda disappointed. I feel like they have a lot of building blocks for making a great game but it's not living up to its potential. The main gripe I have is with how unpolished the English UI is. There's spacing issues, obvious translation mistakes/oddities that hiring ONE fluent English speaker could iron out. I also don't like how you can't zoom the board out more, I had a hard time learning what's going on by playing and planning out was a bit harder as a result. I also had a hard time really understanding the combat system? I understood 100% orange juice's (a game which is impossible NOT to mention in a review for this game) combat system in a snap, but  this games' just didn't make sense. It feel like you roll a die then you get your attack buffs and then it triggers a third time where sometimes the attack goes up and sometimes doesn't? It's weird.

Strangely the main game mode is PvE, seems like that's what all the events want you to play and most lobbies are open for that game mode. The game felt SO slow though. Compared to 100% Orange Juice the games felt like they took FOREVER, even though every action has a timer. I would take my turn then hop on my phone for a few minutes until it was my turn again. It was very slow paced.

Can't speak on the monetization since these are mostly first impressions but I appreciate that characters can be unlocked through events and not just the gacha system. Of course, just selling the characters outright would be less predatory but welcome to 2025.

These are first impressions, I'm gonna stick out until I finish the VA11HALLA collab to give more insight but overall I wish the game was better than it is.

This is where I come back to the point I made about the game speed. The game is horribly slow, a single match can go for upwards of an hour, and you're forced to sit through long and slow movement animations, not to mention the laughably short background music that loops every 30 seconds, making you go insane. Playing this game, even if you're not grinding for characters or items, quickly becomes a chore. You feel like you're being held hostage by the game, and just want it to end as soon as possible, I've even gone as far as helping someone else win because I just wanted it to be over. This is really not an enjoyable experience for anyone involved.

If just playing the game for fun already feels like a chore, imagine trying to grind for characters or items, It would be literally torture. This game need a speed slider ASAP, I think this is the biggest issue the devs need to address, and it shouldn't take them too long considering they are using Unity, just change the global animation speed multiplier and you'll instantly make this a more enjoyable experience.

The devs should really aim for 15 minute matches if they want this game to succeed, ESPECIALLY if they plan to make this a mobile game. This is the kind of game you'll want to play in between work shifts, during short breaks or during your commute, having matches go on for longer than 15 minutes is simply unacceptable in those contexts, let alone 1 hour.

I really can't recommend this game in its current state, even early access games are usually far more polished than this, this really feels like a prototype more than an official release. However, the core gameplay is really fun and I think this game as a lot of potential, so if/when the devs fix the issues described here (especially the speed, PLEASE), I'll change my review to match. Until then, I won't play or recommend this game.

TL;DR: VERY unpolished game, matches are too long and feel like a chore, confusing gacha mechanics. Has potential if it fixes those issues, but overall it was released TOO early.

I was really excited for this game when it was announced, it seemed like a more modern version of 100% Orange Juice, the character designs are extremely appealing, and on top of that, there were hints that this would eventually release as a mobile game (I've always wanted a version of 100%OJ that could be played on the go).

When the demo dropped, I was very underwhelmed, the game was clearly far from finished, there were a lot of translation bugs, things that are essential for card games like a card history are simply missing, and the UI is far from polished (some menus literally use default Unity UI elements, ffs), but, worst of all, there was no setting to adjust the game speed, I'll talk more about this later because it's very important for this kind of game, but the main point is, it didn't seem like a game that was supposed to launch a month later, heck, I'd even dare to say it needed at least a year of polish before being in a presentable state for an official launch,

I thought to myself "there is no way this demo represents the current stage of development of the game, it surely must have been compiled a few months ago", and "maybe they will collect feedback from the demo and most problems should be fixed by release". Boy was I wrong.

Where do I start? Most of the game is exactly the same as the demo, the translation errors still remain, card history is still missing, the UI is still hot garbage, and the gameplay itself is still painfully slow, with no option to accelerate it. The only thing that changed between the demo and the official release was the inclusion of the gacha mechanic and other F2P elements.

Let me start by saying I have no problem with the gacha mechanic itself, after all this is a F2P game, it must make money somehow, although I can't avoid thinking it's kind of a cash grab since the game itself is crowdfunded on top of that, especially since the prices are outrageous: almost 15 USD for 10 rolls. You can only buy rolls with real currency btw, no option to use the in-game premium currency (which you can also buy with real money). Speaking of currencies, there are like SEVEN different in-game currencies, and the game makes almost 0 effort in trying to explain you what each one is for or how to get them, you'll have to figure that out by yourself.

Most of the issues I just described are no big deal, because both the premium currency and the gacha rolls can be grinded by playing and completing missions, so as long as the gameplay is fun, everything is fine, right?

This is where I come back to the point I made about the game speed. The game is horribly slow, a single match can go for upwards of an hour, and you're forced to sit through long and slow movement animations, not to mention the laughably short background music that loops every 30 seconds, making you go insane. Playing this game, even if you're not grinding for characters or items, quickly becomes a chore. You feel like you're being held hostage by the game, and just want it to end as soon as possible, I've even gone as far as helping someone else win because I just wanted it to be over. This is really not an enjoyable experience for anyone involved.

If just playing the game for fun already feels like a chore, imagine trying to grind for characters or items, It would be literally torture. This game need a speed slider ASAP, I think this is the biggest issue the devs need to address, and it shouldn't take them too long considering they are using Unity, just change the global animation speed multiplier and you'll instantly make this a more enjoyable experience.

The devs should really aim for 15 minute matches if they want this game to succeed, ESPECIALLY if they plan to make this a mobile game. This is the kind of game you'll want to play in between work shifts, during short breaks or during your commute, having matches go on for longer than 15 minutes is simply unacceptable in those contexts, let alone 1 hour.

I really can't recommend this game in its current state, even early access games are usually far more polished than this, this really feels like a prototype more than an official release. However, the core gameplay is really fun and I think this game as a lot of potential, so if/when the devs fix the issues described here (especially the speed, PLEASE), I'll change my review to match. Until then, I won't play or recommend this game.

TL;DR: VERY unpolished game, matches are too long and feel like a chore, confusing gacha mechanics. Has potential if it fixes those issues, but overall it was released TOO early.
